My favorite strategy game. Very relaxing. Highly recommend!

Okay so I have over 450 hours in this game and still intend on adding more. This game scratches my need for a good RTS game, yet also brings a fresh style/gameplay to the genre. It has different gameplay styles for Co-op which is something I have always wanted in my RTS style games. Especially when it adds modifiers to bring out some buffs and extra fun. The Bifrost mode is both really enjoyable and cooperative intensive yet frustratingly hard sometimes. This game really does bring out so much of the fun in RTS that I could only hope other games of the genre incorporate into their games Co-op modes. I also cant wait for the upcoming December update that should be adding more to these modes.

Now things I have noticed that others have also mentioned. Yes after long playtimes there seems to be something that causes lag or some kind of connection issues when you didn't have an ounce of them before. Doesn't seem to matter which connection you choose either, after about 806-809 AD time in game, it seems to struggle to keep a good connection in any game mode. Or You will experience lag or time stops for only one of the players.
To be fair though, these are nothing compared to the struggles we had when this game first came out with its multiplayer, that was a nightmare, constant drops, constant lag. Now it seems to really only affect long timed games. I Hope to see more updates and fixes on these soon.

Besides that, the rest of the game is amazing and enjoyable and I can repeat the Conquest and Bifrost modes with friends over and over and I enjoy the small rewards/cosmetics for your first completions. I would recommend maybe adding another cosmetic for regular villagers, one for each clan maybe? Maybe getting that cosmetic would be by completing a second Conquest with that clan? Or each time you Complete a Bifrost with a clan for the first time? Just ways to suggest even more replayability in these modes. I hope some more fixes for the connection stuff come with the new update and extended game modes. I hope we see even more new clans. Even though everyone says they are just reskins of the same clans, once you play each one and try playing them in the Co-op modes, they really do have different checks and balances that can make each map harder or easier. 

Also the whole "THE BOTS CHEAT" thing is true, instead of other games like Age of Mythology as an example, making each Bot act exactly like a player. The Bots get an auto income of resources regardless of how many plots they have, can summon their villagers in a wave of 3 sometimes, and can resummon their Warchief even without mining Iron or Stone. But I get why this is easier than forcing the Bots to act and resource manage like the player for a higher challenge as well as its easier on the developers and coding. Yet I won't deny its irritating to watch the Bots with three land plots or several empty plots pushing troops like its free and sending waves at objectives or your own land to try to steal. Especially early on when you are just trying to get enough food and wood for winter. So maybe the suggestion could be to fix this, or limit how much auto resources they get and make them at least have to act more like the player?

I highly suggest this game for anyone who likes an RTS with a bit of a twist on the resource grab/management style. If you liked AOM, SC2, WC3, AOE, DoW or any games similar to those, this game scratches those itches, while still being different in its own way. This game is awesome and fun and with the continuation of updates and features on the way I am still as excited and stoked with playing time and time again with my friends as I was in the beginning.

Northgard is a fun but often frustrating game which lets you manage a small colony against a wide variety of threats. These threats range from wolves to ravenous foxes, mystical creatures, draugurs, starvation, cold, the kraken, etc. etc. and of course... your enemy.

I really enjoyed this game and have spent most of my time in the conquest mode, playing on the hardest difficulty with all base clans. I have one major complaints is that it feels the AI gets a large amount of cheats, often fielding armies 3-4x the size of my army by the time I meet them. They can usually be cheesed or whittled down but you cannot beat some combinations of terrain and AI aggression. (tip: If you retreat from a neutral land, the AI usually retreats back to their land. This can be repeated infinitely I believe.) You can usually scratch by with food but this also can be very tight, every game tends to have different challenges.

[b]This is not a micro heavy game[/b], it favors efficient use of your villagers and you never control very many units in your army for the base game. I kind of like this, and its worth trying for the base game. The biggest problem I have with it is when first encountering DLC factions it can "feel" unfair especially against Dragonkin, but you are usually able to make it through. Don't be afraid to reset the map in Conquest, I have seen spawns that seem impossible, even to me.

Some specific complaints:
1. POPUPS DURING COMBAT - Having to click twice has cost me a few units over my time playing the game.
2. Game tends to favor grouping up your army into one death ball, there is very little reason to split except for abusing AI.
3. Military is too expensive, it's very difficult for the player to replace it, even with a large population. Perhaps adding a gold upkeep would work better, definitely could help with mad rushes to defend. Using your villagers in combat is an effective strategy and can work in a crunch to swing back, but this is a surefire way to starve in the short term. (The AI never does this.)
4. You cannot tell your towers what unit to attack, it would also be nice to build an additional tower.

Some of my favorite things to do:
1. Steal enemy Altar of Kings
2. Outmanuever the silly bots and kill lonely units, especially warchiefs. It's very hard for them to bounce back.
3. With the Wolf Clan, hunting is well done and fun.
4. Starve for most of the game until I finally get enough land to stop starving.

Review:

If you're a fan of strategy games that offer a perfect balance of resource management, exploration, and combat, then Northgard is a hidden gem you absolutely shouldnâ€™t miss. Set in a vibrant world inspired by Norse mythology, this real-time strategy game takes you on an epic journey to colonize and conquer a wild, untamed land.

The beauty of Northgard lies in its simplicity and depth. The core mechanics are easy to grasp, but the strategic decisions you make are anything but simple. You control a clan of Vikings, and your main goal is to expand your territory, gather resources, build up your settlement, and defend it from both the harsh environment and rival clans. Whether youâ€™re managing your villagers, deciding where to build structures, or planning military campaigns, the decisions you make always feel impactful.

What I love:

Unique Faction Playstyles: Each clan in Northgard comes with its own unique abilities, strengths, and playstyles. Whether you're leading the aggressive Wolf Clan, the resourceful Raven Clan, or the peaceful Elk Clan, every faction feels different and offers a fresh challenge.

Stunning Art Direction: The art style is gorgeous! The world of Northgard is full of rich forests, snowy mountains, and peaceful lakes, all brought to life with stunning visuals. The animation is fluid, and itâ€™s easy to get lost in the beautiful Nordic landscape.

Challenging Survival Elements: This game isnâ€™t just about building an empire; itâ€™s also about surviving. The environment can be unforgiving, with harsh winters that threaten your food supply and wildlife that can attack your settlement. Surviving through these conditions is a constant challenge that makes each game feel intense and rewarding.

Multiplayer and Replayability: The multiplayer mode is fantastic, allowing you to compete with friends or random players in competitive matches. Plus, with different maps, factions, and strategies, each game feels fresh and offers high replayability.

What could be improved:

AI Behavior: While the game does a great job at offering a challenge, the AI could use a bit more refinement in some of the later stages. Occasionally, enemy clans seem to take actions that are a bit too predictable, making them easier to counter.

Resource Management in the Late Game: As you expand and grow your settlement, resource management can sometimes feel a bit overwhelming. More automation options or clearer ways to manage your growing empire would be a welcome addition for players who want to focus more on strategic decision-making and less on micromanagement.

Overall:
Northgard is an incredibly well-rounded strategy game that offers a fantastic experience for fans of resource management, survival, and tactical gameplay. Its Norse-inspired world, combined with unique factions and challenging survival mechanics, make it a game thatâ€™s hard to put down. Whether youâ€™re in it for the story, the strategic depth, or just the pure fun of exploration and conquest, Northgard delivers in every way.

Final Verdict: 8/10 â€“ A charming and challenging strategy game with plenty of replayability. A must-try for fantasy Viking and RT strategy enthusiasts!

The game was fun after learning the basics, but few things ruined it for me.

First is performance. For unknown reason the game got laggy so badly in the late game, even though I play single player and there was only 1 enemy left. My population is <40. Even after defeating the enemy, it still lags. My computer did not struggle to run the game though, so I don't know what is causing the FPS drop and lag.

Second is balance. Story mode is fine, but conquest is horrible. It doesn't make sense to play in normal difficulty where 4 enemies just attack you, 2-3 clans at one time (while you are fending off wolf/fox/draugr attack from neighboring tile). Worse if the enemy is dragon clan with their ridiculously powerful army and somehow the AI can amass such big army 20 minutes into the game.

Lastly and the most forgivable one is bad UX:
1. Clicking your unit automatically scrolls the map to the unit. So if you want a unit to build in a different tile, you need to create the building in the tile, click on the unit (not villager) which scrolls to it, then move to the building tile to ask it to build. It gets crazy in the late game when your settlement is inevitably occupy large tiles as each can only support 3-4 buildings.
2. Notification sometimes cover the entire screen, so when you're in the middle of doing something (e.g selecting what to upgrade in blacksmith, browsing trade route choices), the entire process is aborted. And if you accidentally clicked on anything in the screen, that huge notification is gone without trace, so I don't know what was that.

From gameplay mechanic perspective, the game is quite bloated. The game has 9 types of resource (food, wood, stone, iron, krown (money), lore, fame, military experience, happiness). N I N E! That is more than 4x Warcraft3 and 2x Age of Empires. Your villagers will struggle trying to balance them without drowned in curse of dimensionality.

This is a very interesting and visually striking strategy game, but unfortunately, itâ€™s severely hampered by functional bugs and questionable design choices. On paper, the concept is great you manage which buildings to place in each region you control, expand your territory, and defend your lands from invaders. Sounds promising, right? Unfortunately, in practice, it falls short. Even a simple threat, like a lone wolf, can wipe out multiple villagers because the defensive systems are poorly balanced. Youâ€™re limited to only one tower per region, and that single tower is almost useless in combat enemies often destroy it without taking a single casualty. This leaves you relying almost entirely on your warriors, who are very limited in number. You constantly face a frustrating choice  spread your units thin to defend multiple areas and risk losing villagers, or focus on attacking and watch your population dwindle. The balance makes little sense. Towers should either be far stronger, or there shouldnâ€™t be any restriction on the number you can build. Villagers themselves are also far too fragile, leaving defensive gameplay repetitive and often pointless. Natural disasters, like earthquakes, create additional headaches by setting buildings on fire while your villagers stand idly by. Micromanaging repairs at such a granular level becomes tedious and breaks the flow of the game. It would have been far more engaging if villagers could automatically repair damage or handle minor threats on their own. Despite its problems, the game still has a lot of potential. The strategy elements, territorial expansion, and building management are interesting, and the visuals are impressive. This is a very interesting and visually striking strategy game, but unfortunately, itâ€™s severely hampered by functional bugs and questionable design choices. On paper, the concept is great you manage which buildings to place in each region you control, expand your territory, and defend your lands from invaders. Sounds promising, right? Unfortunately, in practice, it falls short. Even a simple threat, like a lone wolf, can wipe out multiple villagers because the defensive systems are poorly balanced. Youâ€™re limited to only one tower per region, and that single tower is almost useless in combat enemies often destroy it without taking a single casualty. This leaves you relying almost entirely on your warriors, who are very limited in number. You constantly face a frustrating choice  spread your units thin to defend multiple areas and risk losing villagers, or focus on attacking and watch your population dwindle. The balance makes little sense. Towers should either be far stronger, or there shouldnâ€™t be any restriction on the number you can build. Villagers themselves are also far too fragile, leaving defensive gameplay repetitive and often pointless. Natural disasters, like earthquakes, create additional headaches by setting buildings on fire while your villagers stand idly by. Micromanaging repairs at such a granular level becomes tedious and breaks the flow of the game. It would have been far more engaging if villagers could automatically repair damage or handle minor threats on their own. Despite its problems, the game still has a lot of potential. The strategy elements, territorial expansion, and building management are interesting, and the visuals are impressive. With better balancing and smarter automation, it could easily become a standout strategy title but as it stands, the bugs and design flaws make it a frustrating experience.

It doesn't make sense to play in normal difficulty where 4 enemies just attack you, 2-3 clans at one time (while you are fending off wolf/fox/draugr attack from neighboring tile). Worse if the enemy is dragon clan with their ridiculously powerful army and somehow the AI can amass such big army 20 minutes into the game.

Lastly and the most forgivable one is bad UX:
1. Clicking your unit automatically scrolls the map to the unit. So if you want a unit to build in a different tile, you need to create the building in the tile, click on the unit (not villager) which scrolls to it, then move to the building tile to ask it to build. It gets crazy in the late game when your settlement is inevitably occupy large tiles as each can only support 3-4 buildings.
2. Notification sometimes cover the entire screen, so when you're in the middle of doing something (e.g selecting what to upgrade in blacksmith, browsing trade route choices), the entire process is aborted. And if you accidentally clicked on anything in the screen, that huge notification is gone without trace, so I don't know what was that.

From gameplay mechanic perspective, the game is quite bloated. The game has 9 types of resource (food, wood, stone, iron, krown (money), lore, fame, military experience, happiness). N I N E! That is more than 4x Warcraft3 and 2x Age of Empires. Your villagers will struggle trying to balance them without drowned in curse of dimensionality.
